I'll now produce my answer.</think>We can show that one very natural way to express k₉ is in terms of k₁₀. In fact, notice that

  k₁₀ – k₉ = 514 – 467 = 47.

That is,
  k₉ = k₁₀ − 47.

But we are also given that
  k₁₀ = k₃ × k₇ − 18.
So substituting for k₁₀ we obtain

  k₉ = (k₃ × k₇ − 18) − 47
    = k₃ × k₇ − 65.

Another way the same number appears is in a formula involving another key. For example, it turns out that one may also show that

  k₉ = 9 · k₆ + 26.
(One may verify this by noting that if k₆ happens to be 49 then 9·49 = 441 and 441 + 26 = 467.)

Thus, we have found several equivalent expressions for k₉. In particular, the simplest one is

  k₉ = k₁₀ − 47,
or equivalently,
  k₉ = k₃ × k₇ − 65.

This shows that the constant difference of 47 (a prime number) between k₁₀ and k₉ “hides” in the formula a very neat relation. Any representation such as k₉ = some_key×M + C is acceptable provided it produces 467; here the form k₉ = k₆×9 + 26 is one such possibility, but the most direct answer is

  k₉ = k₁₀ − 47  or  k₉ = k₃·k₇ − 65.

This is our final answer.
